awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Shape Model Selection:  Theory and Practice
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores shape models that unite human shape perception, computational tractability and mathematical rigor. In particular, it establishes geometry-based selection criteria for skeletal models, defining the best model to be the one that requires the fewest bits to approximate within a specified error tolerance. The goals of the project are to develop theoretical results establishing selection criteria for skeletal models and to apply those results to shape-dependent industrial projects.

Skeletal shape models are attractive for shape-based applications because they decompose shapes into salient parts that can be manipulated independently. Their primary downfall for practical applications, a lack of robustness to noises in the shape boundary, has only recently been addressed. In the classical definition of the skeletal model, each shape has a unique skeleton. That uniqueness creates a geometric rigidity that in turn leads to the lack of robustness. A recent generalized skeletal definition relaxes the uniqueness constraint, allowing multiple skeletal models for each shape. Multiple models provide the flexibility to accommodate noisy shape boundaries, but introduce a new problem in selecting the best skeletal model for a given shape.

The project engages capable but disadvantaged students who would otherwise be unaware of research as a career in exciting and relevant research. Broader impacts include extensive collaboration between research students and future teachers to develop learning activities for K-12 classrooms, development of course modules to incorporate concepts from digital image analysis into standard sophomore-level mathematics courses, and development of industrial applications in collaboration with students and industrial partners.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project were to (1) provide application-independent reasons grounded in solid mathematical theory for selecting an approximating skeleton to represent a two-dimensional shape, (2) explore applications of skeletal shape models to problems arising from government and industry, and (3) engage the broader community with imaging. 

1. Skeleton Selection: Skeletal models for 2D and 3D shapes allow for decomposition of shapes into parts, articulation of parts, and global stability in the face of local perturbation. Contributions of the project in this area include developing a shape structure in two and three dimensions that computes and links decomposition of parts, hierarchy of parts, and similarity between parts into a cohesive whole; a skeletal branch salience measure that identifies the most important "directions" within a shape; an algorithm for extracting salient skeletal fragments from an image that can then be matched into a template skeleton dictionary; and a novel definition of persistent shape complexity applied to define clusters of shapes with similar complexity. In addition, we contributed two user study databases to provide benchmarks for shape decomposition and hierarchies and for parts similarity, and a code base for reproducing our results. The databases and code are freely available to the public.

2. Applications to government and industry: We applied these skeletal methods to a range of applications, including fire growth modeling, strawberry stem detection for automated harvesting, whale individual identification, dance pose recognition, movement of swimming fish, and schizophrenia diagnosis. These projects involved input from a wide range of disciplines and organizations, including choreographers, neuroscientists, geologists, biologists, and farmers.

3. Engagement with imaging: With undergraduate math education students collaborating with research students, we developed dozens of in-class activities to teach mathematical concepts through imaging activities. We published a revised linear algebra class with student projects in image analysis illustrating key linear algebra results. We organized two research collaboration workshops for women (2013, 2016) bringing together mathematicians, computer scientists, and engineers, ranging from graduate students to senior researchers, several of whom had never worked in image analysis, to begin collaborating on research projects in shape modeling. Finally, we initiated a collaboration with artists to develop artwork and other products at the interface of technology and society.

This project has engaged almost 30 undergraduate students, over half of whom are women or from an underrepresented ethnic group, in original research projects during the academic year. Of those students, half have gone to graduate school, with seven to complete a PhD in computational field in the next year or two. Among their awards are Goldwater Fellowships, NSF Graduate Fellowships, and an invitation to present their work on Capitol Hill (Posters on the Hill). The project has also involved several recent PhDs from the US and Europe who have since been successfully hired into tenure track positions. Additional awards related to this work include best paper awards, teaching awards, and an award for service to the Association for Women in Mathematics.
